awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Integrated Research Instrument for Large Animal Testing Investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT Sankar  1229392
This proposal is requesting funding for instrumentation suitable for 'large' animal testing and characterization of bio-implant materials. They are specifically considering a HR micro-CT with XRF feature and a multi-photon confocal microscope. These two pieces are used in tandem  to completely image whole bady animal models. The requested capability will enable Micro-surgery in animals, in vivo real-time 3D monitoring and in vivo imaging, for evaluating deep tissue. The implants will be designed to provide optimum therapy when required and to bio-dissolve when no longer needed. Such innovations would particularly benefit pediatric cleft palate patients, angular deformities of long bones, limb length discrepancies, or trauma including fractures that require pins and screws for repair. Other areas of application include osteoporotic fragility fractures in aging baby boomers (wrist, hip and spine) and reconstruction of multiple rib fractures (trauma).
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

por.por_cntn:
Many orthopedic device researchers struggle with the need to demonstrate feasibility of early materials development and its assessments in relevant animal models, while ensuring the health of animals. This grant was awarded for instrumentation suitable for animal testing and characterization of bio-implant materials using an in vivo micro-CT, XRF elemental characterization, and a multi-photon confocal microscope. These systems are to be used to thoroughly image implant areas in animal models in support of developing and investigating various novel bioengineered materials (especially biodegradable ones) in large animals. Animal research is a vital and critical component of biomedical research and implant innovation potentials. Overall, biodegradable metallic systems offer significant therapeutic advantages over implants used today. The promise is that new kinds of implants and biodegradable metals may be used that can optimally facilitate the healing process and eventually dissolve when no longer needed. A primary purpose of this funding is to correlate multi-photon confocal optical images (and related fluorescence techniques) with other animal imaging technologies used and being developed at North Carolina Agricultural and Technological State University (NC A&T) and local collaborators such x-ray transmission (CT), x-ray fluorescence (XRF), electron microscopy (SEM), and histological analyses.

Further, this grant has positively impacted research and education as measured by student achievement, industrial collaborations, publications, and awarded grants. In addition, the culture of research and intra-dependency of operations at NC A&T has been improved through the inter-department nature of this project and involvement of Information Technologies to assist on and off campus translation of data sets. It is expected that the instrument package will continue to be a key element of the success of researchers, collaborators, and students.

Disclaimer:

"This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content."

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2017
Modified by: Jagannathan Sankar
